posts.name: Jack brannon
posts.cooked: My team is organizing off-season workshops for middle and high school students to introduce them to FIRST and robotics. We're seeking ideas for electrical-themed activities that go beyond PowerPoint presentations and test board demonstrations.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Have them wire up the test board with crimping and soldering.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Small Arduino projects are fun, can be short, and immediately demonstrate how code controls circuits. Reaction tester games, LED control, and relay systems, such as potentiometers linked to servos, provide engaging examples. There are numerous resources available for learning these concepts, including tutorials and documentation.

link_counts.title: A Simple Reflex Game | Arduino Project Hub
Arduino - Servo Motor controlled by Potentiometer | Arduino Tutorial

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: We obtained kits containing six different soldering projects to create devices with sound and light effects. Each kit costs approximately $35 and includes six projects; we purchased multiple kits, one for each student. Most students found the activity enjoyable. Unfortunately, we no longer recall the exact electronic hobby kit company we sourced from, but numerous projects are available online ranging from $5 to $35 each.

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: At a local Maker Faire, a group was engaged in a small soldering activity utilizing a custom PCB. They would solder a battery and a LED using through-hole components. The PCB featured a design suitable for the Maker Faire and included a spot for an additional pin, allowing participants to wear it. This brief activity promised to be both enjoyable and reasonably priced.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Learn the basics of soldering by creating your very own blinking LED rocket ship pin. A favorite Maker Faire activity, soldering is an excellent skill to enhance your crafting abilities.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked: I and then receive a soldering kit for this post. A soldering kit. Then they get to keep it when done. There are so many to pick from.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I've successfully cleaned up the text according to your specifications. Let me know if you have any further requests!

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Lead solder Just ignore the skull and crossbones warning on the package  
The roll we have has one on it and the students always wonder why we keep it As long as you have eye protection (should be on anyways when using any tools) nitrile gloves use a smoke absorber and don’t eat it you’ll be fine.  

Also if you have lots of extra “junk” wire they can practice the “NASA-splice”.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: We welcome you to our new project. In this project, team members will collaborate on innovative technologies. We're excited to share more details soon.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: For Jbrannon I found the soldering kits my team bought. I am concerned about the recent significant increase in price. There are also other soldering kits available on this website including the 4-in-1 Learn to Solder product. Additionally the List of Kits page offers comprehensive resources for various soldering projects.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Old school eutectic Lead solder is way easier than the modern Lead free stuff. Yes, it's a bit hotter and you have to wash your hands afterwards, but that smooth action and “if its shiny its a good joint” thing rocks. So worth it!

Leaded eutectic solder has a lower melting point than no-lead eutectic solder. (That’s one of the reasons it’s harder to learn no-lead, IMO, because the flux is more prone to burning off before the metal melts.)

Leaded solder is easier to learn and I think more forgiving overall. But it mixes really poorly with no-lead solder and a lot of what we do in electronics is repair/rework of existing items [most of the new items are no-lead/RoHS], and it’s even harder to have a mix of leaded and no-lead/RoHS items on the same tools/bench.

With that in mind, at home I’ve almost entirely switched over to no-lead for new work and have one small soldering station that I keep for leaded work.

Another tip: give your students access to an external flux pen and/or syringe. Nothing teaches them more quickly about the purpose/utility of a clean joint than struggling with a joint for a while and then seeing how much easier it is with added fresh flux.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Good points there! Oddly enough at SLB we actually have some soldering stations specifically for lead-free solder because we need the higher melting point; its referred to as HMP solder. Downhole tools get HOT Cross contamination can lead to components falling off downhole I’ll have to see about a flux pen sounds like a great demo
When I mistakenly believed that a CAN bus was a loop instead of a bus, I created a controller area network bracelet using an additional wire.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: It’s fun to watch all your components sliding off the board through the window in the test oven door when the wrong solder was used.
